Review Dual metal atom catalysts: Advantages in electrocatalytic reactions Kaihua Liu ⁎ Jing Li Yuanyuan Liu Meiri Wang Hongtao Cui College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, Shandong, China College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Yantai University Yantai 264005 Shandong China College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The advantages of DACs in various electrocatalytic reactions are summarized, also including the characterization methods, synthesis strategies, and prospects of DACs. The dual-metal-atom catalysts (DACs) have aroused much attention as they possess the advantages of single-atom and metal alloy catalysts. And the DACs have exhibited enhanced performance in various electrocatalytic reactions, such as hydrogen/oxygen evolution and oxygen/carbon dioxide/nitrogen reduction. In this review, we mainly overview the latest understanding of the advantages of DACs for these reactions. This review will start with the familiar characterization methods for DACs, then the primary synthesis strategies for DACs will be discussed. Emphasis is given to the advantages of DACs in catalytic reactions, including the adsorption and activation, electronic structure regulation, breaking scaling relations, reducing energy barriers, cascading and coupling, synergy effect, and providing mechanism research platforms. Finally, personal perspectives and challenges for the further development of DACs are briefly discussed. Keywords Dual atom catalysts Synergy effect Scaling relation Mechanism study platform 1 Introduction The increasing energy and environmental demands stimulate the rapid development of high-efficiency energy storage and conversion techniques [1–4]. Thereinto, most of them mainly rely on several crucial electrochemical reactions, such as hydrogen/oxygen evolution reaction (HER/OER), oxygen/carbon dioxide/ nitrogen reduction reaction (ORR/CO2RR/NRR), etc. [5,6]. Thus, the implementation of these techniques extensively relies on fabricating efficient electrocatalysts to improve energy conversion efficiency. And the advanced catalysts for these reactions until now are still noble-metal catalysts (Pt, Ru, Au, etc.) [7–10]. However, their large-scale application is greatly restricted by their scarcity and stability [11]. Therefore, reducing noble-metal loading or constructing non-noble-metal alternatives is still the focus of current research. Single-atom catalysts (SACs), once reported by Zhang et al. in 2011 [12], have attracted considerable research interests in these thriving fields. The single atom of noble-metal catalysts, which could minimize the precious metal loading while maintaining the maximum atomic utilization, has exhibited enhanced performance towards many reactions, such as Mo2TiC2T x -PtSA for HER [13], Ru/MnO2 for acidic OER [14], Ir-SAC for ORR [15], and Au1/C3N4 for NRR [16], etc. Besides, the unique electronic and locally coordinated structures of SACs contribute to adjusting the adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates. Thus, the SACs almost all display the optimized reaction barrier to promote the reaction process [17–19]. Many reviews have discussed the development of SACs [20–22]. However, limited by the atomically isolated single active site, SACs may not be the optimal catalysts for multiple intermediates reactions. Therefore, as the extension of SACs, the dual-metal-atom catalysts (DACs) have recently drawn ever-rising attention due to their more than one kind of adsorption sites, which can not only further optimize the adsorption/desorption properties, but also provide more adjacent and interactional active sites to couple the reaction pathways to accelerate reactions [23–29]. Considering the fast growth of this field, a timely review could help to promptly understand the advantages of DACs for these reactions and provide guidance for designing efficient catalysts. Herein, we summarize the recent development of DACs in these fields, and only discuss that the two metal atoms are adjacent and bridged (Scheme 1 ). Some important characterization methods will be introduced first. Then the typical synthetic strategies will be discussed. Emphasis is given to the latest understanding of the advantages of DACs for different catalytic reactions, clarifying the relationship between structure/composition and catalytic activities. Finally, personal perspectives about the challenges and directions for DACs are presented. 2 Characterization methods Currently, direct proofs for the structural characterization of DACs are still insufficient because of the limitations of catalysts and characterization techniques [21]. Thus, the characterization of DACs always needs a series of complementary techniques [30,31]. Herein, we summarize some of the most widely used techniques for the characterization of DACs, including their unique advantages and limitations (Fig. 1 ). 2.1 Electron microscopy Advanced electron microscopy can directly provide atomic-resolution imaging of heterogeneous catalysts. Especially, the aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) mode is widely applied for the characterization of SACs [6]. However, only the HAADF-STEM image makes it hard to distinguish atoms with similar atomic number, or obtain information about chemical surroundings of metal atoms. This may require the participation of electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) to further obtain atomic-resolution chemical information [32]. Thus, we should combine the HAADF-STEM images, EELS, and EDX to get more accurate information about the components of catalysts. These techniques have become indispensable characterization tools for DACs. For example, Zhang et al. used the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and STEM images to demonstrate the absence of nanoparticles in the Ni dual-atom catalyst (Ni2NC) [33]. Then the AC HAADF-STEM image showed the average distance of these adjacent dots was 0.25 nm, close to that of the simulated value (0.24 nm). The Ni dual atom anchored on NC was further verified using EELS. And the elemental mapping suggested the Ni, N, and C were distributed uniformly on Ni2NC (Fig. 2 a–d). Moreover, they also used in situ environmental scanning transmission electron microscopy (ESTEM) to detect the forming process of the Ni DAC during pyrolysis, which included the formation of the bulk phase by Ostwald ripening and then an atomization process for transforming the bulk phase to dual atoms (Fig. 2e). However, it is difficult to distinguish the single atoms in different depths because of the “transmission” signals [21]. Besides, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) can be used for describing catalyst structure on an atomic scale, but the extremely high-test difficulty and the fact that it can be applied only on an atomically flat surface make it unfriendly for most catalysts [34]. Thus, we do not discuss it any more here. 2.2 X-ray absorption spectroscopy The X-ray absorption spectrum (XAS) is another indispensable means to characterize the DACs, especially in the valence, coordination environment, and structural parameters. The oxidation state of metal can be deduced from the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES), and the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) can provide more detailed information about the coordination environment of catalysts via the Fourier or wavelet transform (FT or WT) analysis and EXAFS fitting [35]. This valuable information contributes to understanding the structural models of metal active centers for further theoretical studies. One example of the XAS characterization for Ni–Zn atomic pair is shown in Fig. 3 [36]. The Ni valence of Ni–ZnNC was between + 1 and + 2, as the Ni XANES edge was between Ni foil and NiO (Fig. 3a). Fig. 3(b) showed the similar result for Zn. The major peaks at 1.29 Å in Fig. 3(c) and 1.45 Å in Fig. 3(d) were assigned to the Ni–N and Zn–N coordination, respectively. Besides, the peaks at 1.99 Å in Fig. 3(c) and 2.28 Å in Fig. 3(d) suggested their electronic interactions. No WT signal of Ni–Ni bond suggested the absence of nanoparticles in catalysts, and the signal at 8.9 Å−1 in Fig. 3(e) was attributed to Ni–Zn interaction paths. Moreover, the EXAFS curves of Ni–ZnNC fit well with the experimental results (Fig. 3g and h). Based on the EXAFS fitting and theoretical simulation, the metal atoms were coordinated with three N atoms. The XAS technique is also applied to in-situ/operando measurements to detect valence and structural changes of active centers under working conditions. For example, operando XANES spectroscopy combined with DFT calculations was used to demonstrate the structural evolution of an atomically dispersed Cu2+-N4 structure to Cu+–N3 and then to HO-Cu+–N2 under ORR process [37]. And the potential-induced restructuring of the Cu2+ reduction and the aggregation of Cu0 single atoms was demonstrated during the electrochemical synthesis of NH3 from nitrate. Interestingly, the aggregated nanoparticles can be reversibly restored to the Cu-N4 structure after electrolysis [38]. Significantly, the structure information deduced from XAS is an average result, which indicates that an inaccurate structure will be obtained if the catalyst contains many different coordination structures. Next, some fitted data, such as the low metal–metal coordination number, and the common coordination elements (C, N, and O) are sometimes difficult to utilize accurately. Thus, the XAS should unite with other characterization techniques to confirm the real coordination structure. 2.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), a high-sensitivity surface chemistry characterization technique, is extensively applied to investigate the bonding information and electronic state. And the shift in peak position and heteroatomic doping can be related to the electrocatalytic performance. For instance, Hu et al. combined the XPS and XAS to demonstrate that pyrrolic type ligands contributed to maintaining the Fe sites as Fe3+ during CO2RR, which contributed to CO2 and CO adsorption [39]. It should be noted that only XPS cannot resolve the coordination environment of metal sites. 2.4 Mössbauer spectroscopy Mössbauer spectroscopy is another powerful technique to detect the local structure and electronic states of Mössbauer-active elements. For example, Li group performed Mössbauer spectroscopic to study the coordination structure of Fe–Co dual sites [40]. Typically, the Fe–Co dual sites catalyst consisted of three FeN4-centers, which were the Fe(II)N4 coordination with Fe(II) in a high-, intermediate-, and low-spin state, respectively. Especially, the singlet component of iron species suggested the presence of Fe–Co bond. Similar to XAS, the Mössbauer spectroscopy includes all types of metal sites in the catalyst. Thus, it may bring the difference in demonstrating the relationship between structure and activity. 2.5 Other characterization techniques Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy is applied to research the chemisorption of probe molecules on different catalysts. The CO adsorption on transition metals can be with the linear (2030–2100 cm−1) and bridge (1750–1950 cm−1) configurations [41]. The bridging adsorption of CO indicates the presence of adjacent adsorption sites. Besides, the metal sites with cationic state would result in a blue-shift of the band position of linear COad [41]. Moreover, the in situ/operando IR spectroscopy, as well as Raman spectroscopy, has been widely applied for investigating the catalysis mechanisms. Besides, the inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) is always used to confirm the metal content in DACs. Moreover, the theoretical simulation is also used to deduce the possible structures of DACs. The other unmentioned characterization methods for atomically dispersed catalysts can be seen in other reviews [20,21]. 3 Synthetic strategies The synthesis of DACs is more challenging because of their unique structural motifs and easy aggregation. This usually means the atomically dispersed dual-atomic-site must be strongly anchored on substrates. Thus, the surface coordination chemistry is crucial for the synthesis and activities of catalysts [21,42]. Here, we concisely summarize the currently reported routes for the synthesis of DACs. 3.1 High temperature pyrolysis High temperature pyrolysis is the general strategy to synthesize the SACs, and also the DACs, which has always employed the metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)/zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) as sacrificial templates because of their accessible ability to realize the atomically dispersed metal atom [43,44]. Wang et al. reported a host–guest design strategy to prepare the Fe-Co dual-site catalyst, which was synthesized via adjusting the bonding between Fe3+ precursors (guest) and Co nodes (host) within the confined space of Zn/Co bimetallic MOF (Fig. 4 a) [40]. And they also prepared the Fe–Co dual sites embedded in N-CNTs by the similar method [45]. Besides, the Zn–Co DAC was prepared through the coordination of metal ions with the amidogen and hydroxyl groups on chitosan chains, and then pyrolysis at 750 °C (Fig. 4b) [46]. Notably, this method can regulate the dispersion of metal atoms easily via the coordination, adsorption, and ion exchange, but the relatively low yields and poor reproducibility hinder its application in scalable synthesis of DACs. 3.2 Wet chemistry The wet chemistry method is typically low cost and easy synthesis to achieve atomic level dispersion. The wet chemistry synthesis process can roughly include introducing the precursors to the host (e.g., precipitation or impregnation) and then post-treatment, such as reduction, oxidation, or thermal treatment [47]. For example, Cu-Pt dual sites alloyed with Pd nanorings (Pd/Cu-Pt NRs) were prepared via introducing CuCl2·2H2O into Pd nanosheets, then introducing HCl solution with K2PtCl4 [48]. Besides, Li et al. used this method to prepare the copper atom-pair on Pd10Te3 nanowires (Fig. 4c) [49]. Especially, the wet-chemical methods always adopt a minor amount of metal precursors to produce atomically dispersed metal sites, but this is not always effective, and is also limited in precisely regulating the location of introduced atoms. 3.3 Electrochemical method The electrochemical method is mainly through electroplating target metal onto the conductive host. This always results in the deposited metal on the surface of supports, which is beneficial for improving the utilization of metal atoms and surface catalytic reactions. Hu et al. synthesized the Co–Fe double-atom catalyst (Co–FeNC) via the transformation of single-atom Co catalyst by this method (Fig. 4d) [50]. The activation process of CoNC can be proceeded in a “normal” KOH solution with a minor amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. The possible formation process may be that the [Fe(OH)4]− species were absorbed on atomically dispersed Co sites under positive potential, resulting in the dimeric Co–Fe units. Moreover, the authors described that this transformation could also be used to prepare other Co/Fe/Ni-based DACs. However, the target catalysts may not be obtained by this method due to the other contaminants in solution, and the adhesion of atoms on the host should also be considered. 3.4 Atomic layer deposition Compared with pyrolyzing two metal precursors simultaneously, the atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique is beneficial for robust control of the structure and composition of catalyst though it always requires special equipment and harsh reaction conditions. Typically, the gas-phase metal precursor is taken to the reaction chamber, and then formed single atomic layer onto the prepared substrate with the help of a second gas reactant. The thickness of deposition can be finely regulated by simply changing the ALD cycles. After the first prepared Pt single atoms on graphene [51], Sun et al. fabricated the Pt-Ru dimers on NCNTs via a two-step ALD process recently, which was the first ALD process to synthesize single Pt atom on NCNTs, and then the second ALD process of Ru atoms. The pre-deposition of Pt was conducive to the subsequent deposit of Ru (Fig. 4e) [52]. Obviously, the DACs can be obtained easily via changing the number of ALD cycles, but this may also lead to produce other nanostructures, such as clusters and nanoparticles. 3.5 Chemical vapor deposition Only using chemical vapor deposition (CVD) to prepare DACs has not been reported, although Wu et al. have used CVD to synthesize the Fe/Co/Mn-based SACs [53]. However, Yang et al. combined the hydrothermal reaction and CVD to synthesize the O-coordinated W-Mo heterodimer anchored in N-doped graphene (W1Mo1-NG) (Fig. 4f) [54]. The hydrothermal reaction was first performed to form the W-Mo species on reduced GO. After freeze-drying, the W1Mo1-NG was finally prepared by CVD treatment. Moreover, the authors also demonstrated the formation mechanism of W1Mo1-NG, including the self-assembly, deoxidization, protonation, anchoring and nitridation (Fig. 4g). The other oxo-linked W-Mo DACs and homonuclear dimers based on Mo and W could also be synthesized by changing the synthesis process. The authors also suggested this synthetic strategy might be suitable for other polyoxometalates systems. Although the CVD process may be scalable for synthesis catalysts, it is still a self-limiting surface reaction, and always requires high temperature and additional treatment steps. 4 Advantages in different reactions 4.1 HER Hydrogen (H2), a clean energy carrier, has been considered a green avenue for alleviating the energy and environmental issues [55]. Thereinto, producing H2 from water splitting via the HER, which is driven by renewable energy resources, agrees well with future sustainable energy supply [56]. This process needs efficient electrocatalysts to improve the energy conversion efficiency. Currently, the research focus is reducing noble metal loading or exploring high-performance non-noble metal alternatives [57]. The efficient water splitting electrocatalysts should possess the low overpotential to achieve the 10 mA cm−2 (η 10), one important parameter to estimate the target electrocatalysts. Besides, the small Tafel slope and high exchange current density (j 0), which mean the superior reaction kinetics process, as well as the ultra-long stability are also needed. The overall HER process can be divided into three possible steps, which are the adsorption of H* (Volmer reaction) and then the H* desorption (Heyrovsky or Tafel reactions), thus forming two different mechanisms [58]. The mechanism can be deduced from the Tafel slope values. More importantly, from the Nørskov principle [59], the HER catalyst should exhibit the proper H* adsorption. This indicates the Gibbs free energy change of the H* adsorption (ΔG H*) should be close to zero [60]. Fortunately, DACs have the unique advantages for tuning the H* adsorption because of the special coordination structure. 4.1.1 Alloying effect Fabricating the atomic level Pt-based alloy catalysts is an attractive method to reduce the noble-metal loading and improve the intrinsic activity of each active site. For this purpose, the mentioned Pd/Cu-Pt NRs catalyst was designed for HER, which exhibited superior HER performance than commercial Pt/C in acidic solution, including the low onset potential of near-zero, 22.8 mV of the η 10, and Tafel slope of 25 mV dec−1. And the catalyst only needs the 50 mV overpotential to achieve the mass current density of 3002 A g−1 (Pd+Pt). DFT calculations demonstrated that the high HER activity was ascribed to the low adsorption of *H, better than that on Pt (111). The single Pt atom was confirmed as the H atoms binding site, and the neighboring Cu atoms further optimized the *H adsorption [48]. From this example, the atomic-level Pt-based alloy catalysts can improve the mass activity and tune the adsorption of intermediates simultaneously because of the size and alloying effects. Although the Pd/Cu-Pt NRs catalyst exhibited enhanced HER performance, the optimal composition of alloy is not clear. Therefore, screening the atomic level Pt-based alloy catalysts with the optimal H binding may be the focus of this field. 4.1.2 Regulating electronic structure The interaction of bimetallic dimer could generate a change in electronic structure, such as the metallicity transformation and electron delocalization, thus enhancing the catalytic performance. The Pt-Ru dimers on NCNTs were demonstrated to undergo the metallicity to covalence transformation, which exhibited superior HER activity with the overpotential of 50 mV to achieve the mass activity of 23.1 A mg−1 [52]. Theoretical studies showed that the superior HER activity was ascribed to the weak adsorption between the hydrogen and unoccupied d xz orbital of Ru. This work demonstrates the metallicity transformation of bimetallic dimer during HER process based on theoretical calculation and crystal field theory, deepening the understanding of bimetallic dimer catalysis, which may extend to other catalytic systems. The mutually optimizing the electronic states of DACs was also revealed in photocatalytic water splitting [61]. Especially, the single atom of Co and Pt on TiO2 with nonbonding Co–O–Pt dimers displayed a superior photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity than Pt SAC and Pt clustered catalysts [62]. The enhanced performance was attributed to the mutually optimized electronic states of Pt and Co sites, thus weakening the H* binding. This result indicates the importance of nonbonding interactive dimer sites. Notably, this oxygen-coordinated nonbonding but interactive bimetallic dimer is not limited by electron-negativity and enthalpy, thus providing more opportunities for developing novel catalysts with new electronic states. But identifying such structures is a complicated process. The electron delocalization of the bimetallic dimer was demonstrated by the O-coordinated W1Mo1-NG [54]. The AC HAADF-STEM image displayed the isolated W–Mo atoms, and the enlarged W–Mo atomic distance indicated the other atom was introduced. Combined with the WT results at Mo K-edge and W L3-edge, as well as the DFT calculations, the authors deduced the most possible structure of this catalyst was W–O–MoOC configuration (Fig. 5 a–f). Due to this synergistic interaction of dual atoms, the W1Mo1-NG catalyst displayed the Pt-like HER activity, including the low onset potential of near-zero and 26, 24, and 67 mV of the η 10, Tafel slope of 30 and 45 mV dec−1, the j 0 of 1.78 and 0.26 mA cm−2, as well as high stability in acidic and alkaline media, respectively. DFT results demonstrated the electron delocalization of W–O–MoOC configuration in W1Mo1-NG provided the optimal ΔGH* and boosted the HER kinetics by reducing the energetic barrier and improving the electrical conductivity, thus synergistically promoting the HER activity (Fig. 5g–i). This work emphasizes the importance of electron delocalization in optimizing the adsorption behavior of H*, which should also be suitable for other catalytic reactions. From these results, the DACs can not only improve the mass activity of precious metals, but also contribute to optimizing the ΔG H* by the alloying effect and regulation of electronic structure, thus synergistically enhancing the activity. Thereinto, the electronic structure regulation can result in the transformation from metallicity to covalence, and the electron delocalization can provide the desirable ΔG H* and enhance reaction kinetics. Thus, applying the DFT calculations to screen and fabricate the Pt or non-precious metal-based DACs with the optimal ΔG H* should be the focus of the further research. 4.2 OER The OER has a crucial influence on electrochemical energy conversion systems [63,64]. And the OER is known as the critical bottleneck for water splitting due to its sluggish kinetics [65]. This leads to that the OER catalysts always exhibit a high overpotential of 300–400 mV. Therefore, tremendous works are to develop efficient OER electrocatalysts to reduce the overpotential. The Co/Fe/Ni-based metal compounds are one of the most efficient heterogeneous OER catalysts in alkaline electrolyte because of the synergy effect of different metals [66–68]. However, the real active center and reaction mechanism are always ambiguous due to the complicated structure of these heterogeneous catalysts. Typically, the OER is a four-electron oxidation reaction and involves the *OH, *O, and *OOH intermediates. Recently, the viewpoint of synergy effect deriving from different components in the same multi-component catalyst has drawn more and more attention [69]. This indicates that if the elementary reactions can proceed on different active sites, the whole reaction process will be out of the limiting between the single active sites and multiple intermediates, which will maximumly accelerate the reaction process. Therefore, one of the critical strategies to fabricate the efficient OER catalysts is how to break this scaling relationship. The DACs may contribute to resolving this issue, and also provide a simple and clear structure model of dual active sites for the fundamental studies. 4.2.1 Synergy effect The synergy effect of DACs for OER is ascribed to the dual atom sites for different intermediates’ adsorption/desorption. For example, the N-coordinated Ni-Fe sites on polymeric carbon nitride (PCN) were prepared for OER [70]. The Ni-Fe dual sites were deduced from the HAADF-STEM image, XAS analysis, Fe Mössbauer spectra and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements. And this catalyst showed a low η 10 of 310 mV and small Tafel slope of 38 mV dec−1 in 1 M KOH. DFT calculations demonstrated the high activity was attributed to the synergistic effect of adjacent Ni and Fe atoms, which served as different active sites for intermediates, leading to a low energy barrier. This work shows that using different types of active sites to adsorb different intermediates could make the elementary reaction proceed smoothly. This is an enormous advantage for DACs, which should be given much attention when designing catalysts for multiple intermediates. Besides, the bimetallic SAC may occur the structural reconstruction into a dual-site catalyst under working conditions. For example, the single Ni sites promoted the structural reconstruction to form the Ni–O–Fe bonds in NiFe SAC through the in situ XAS characterization during water oxidation, which created the spin channels for electron transfer [71]. And a dual-site pathway for OER was provided, which was that the deprotonation of *OH occurred at both Ni and Fe sites, thus forming the O2 on adjacent dual sites (Fig. 6 ). This manifests the structural reconstruction or evolution of the catalyst under working condition. Therefore, revealing the real active site through in-situ characterization techniques contributes to the design of efficient DACs. 4.2.2 Fundamental study platform The DACs provide excellent platforms for OER mechanism study as the complex heterogeneous nature of the Co, Fe, and Ni-based metal oxides [72]. Hu et al. fabricated the Co/Fe/Ni-based DACs from corresponding SACs via an electrochemical method [73]. The distance of these dimers in AC HAADF-STEM images was in the range of 2 to 3 Å, suggesting the Ni–Fe dimer was bridged by oxygen, and this was consistent with the result of EXAFS data. The operando XANES spectra showed the Fe(IV) species were formed in Ni–FeNC under OER conditions (Fig. 7 a). And the authors used the operando K ß high-energy-resolution fluorescence detected (HERFD)-XAS to investigate the characters of frontier orbitals and the bonding state (Fig. 7b), which showed the hybridization between 2p(N/O) and 4p(Ni) states led to the electronic transition from a metal to ligand. The number of Fe ions reached about 25% based on operando HERFD-XAS (Fig. 7c and d). And adding one metal atom to other catalysts can obviously increase the TOFs (Fig. 7e). Finally, the possible reaction mechanism was proposed (Fig. 7f). The Ni(II) ion was firstly oxidized to Ni(III) (S0 → S1). The next step was that the Fe(III)–OH was oxidized to Fe(IV) = O (S1 → S2). The rate-determining step (RDS) was the Fe(III)–OOH formation (S2 → S3). The last step was the O2 formation and regeneration of the Ni(II)–Fe(III) (S3 → S4 → S0). This research not only demonstrates the advantage of bimetallic cooperation in DACs, but also provides the further understanding of heterogeneous catalysts with high OER performance, such as the presence of unusual high valence species (Fe(IV) = O, etc.). From the above examples, the DACs have great potential in multi-intermediates reactions due to the synergy effect, especially that the dual metal atom sites can adsorb different intermediates simultaneous, thus making the elementary reaction proceed smoothly. Besides, the special structural advantage of DACs makes them as attractive platforms to explore the OER mechanism on heterogeneous electrocatalysts, which may extend to other catalytic system. The following research may focus on bimetallic cooperation, stability improvement, and mechanism study to design effective catalysts. The DACs based on the Ru or Ir could also be considered. Various of DACs can exhibit bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis. We will be discussed below. 4.3 ORR The ORR is of utmost importance in fuel cells and metal-air batteries, which are known as vital techniques to resolve the environmental and energy problems [74,75]. However, the application of these techniques is still restricted by the sluggish ORR kinetics, which was induced by the difficulties in O2 adsorption, OO bond activation/cleavage and oxygen intermediates adsorption/desorption [76]. And the ORR can also undergo a two-electron reduction pathway to form H2O2, an important industrial chemical, but this is not desired for above techniques because of the low efficiency of chemical energy conversion and corrosion of the equipment. Pt and its alloys are still the most efficient ORR catalysts, but the properties of noble metals hinder their large-scale application [77]. Thus, developing highly effective low Pt loading or Pt-free catalysts is still the research focus, especially in acidic conditions. In contrast with OER, the ORR also consists of four-electron processes for the O2 reduction to H2O or OH− with the possible OOH*, O*, and OH*intermediates. To boost the sluggish ORR kinetics, the ORR catalysts should be beneficial for O2 adsorption and activation, microenvironmental regulation, and adsorption or desorption of intermediates. Experimentally, the half-wave potential (E 1/2) and mass-transfer-limited current density (j L) are widely used to evaluate the ORR electrocatalysts. The reaction mechanism can also be deduced from Tafel slope. Besides, the transfer number (n), obtained from the Koutecky-Levich equation, is often used to estimate the ORR process. Thanks to the interaction of dual metal atom sites, unique coordination environment, and optimized charge distribution, the DACs display great potential in this field. 4.3.1 Boosting oxygen dissociation Elongating the OO bond is beneficial to its dissociation and thus improves the ORR efficiency [78–80]. DACs have the unique structural advantages for elongating the OO bond due to their adjacent bimetal atom active centers. For example, Yan et al. synthesized the Fe and Cu dual atoms immobilized on N-doped hollow carbon nanospheres (FeCu-N-HC) catalyst, and used the DFT calculations to demonstrate proper adsorption of *OO on the FeCuN6 structure could elongate the OO bond from 1.21 to 1.39 Å [81]. Similarly, the Fe–Co dual sites embedded on NC ((Fe,Co)/NC) [40], and the Zn–Co atomic pairs coordinated on NC (Zn/CoN–C) [46] were also demonstrated to elongate the OO bond to 1.40 and 1.43 Å, respectively. Besides, Xing et al. showed that the triangular FeCoN5-OH provided an optimal eg-orbital energy level for Fe to empower easy intermediate desorption, and a geometry configuration for OO adsorption, which could elongate the OO bond to 1.35 Å, thus facilitating the cleavage of OO bond [82]. Although these studies all demonstrate the elongated OO bond because of the bimetal dimer, the discussion of interactions between the intermediates and active sites, such as the electronic state, is not sufficient. Altering O2 adsorption configuration to effective activation of OO bond can also contribute to oxygen dissociation [83]. The number of clustered Fe atoms could change the O2 adsorption from superoxo-like to peroxo-like configuration toward better activation [84]. And Xie et al. synthesized the planar-like Fe2N6 structure via coupling isolated FeN4 sites [85]. From the operando XAS measurements results (Fig. 8 ), the authors reported that the planar-like Fe2N6 was changed from O x –Fe3+–Fe2+ to Fe2+–Fe2+. The adjacent Fe atoms could each adsorb an oxygenated intermediate to form a dual-side adsorption. Moreover, the authors suggested this redox transition contributed to optimizing oxygen intermediate adsorption and breaking OO bond. Notably, the change of O2 adsorption configuration is the deduced result, which is always relied on the theoretical calculation and data fitting, lacking solid evidence. Overall, fabricating the DACs to elongate the OO bond and/or alter O2 adsorption configuration is beneficial to enhance the ORR performance. 4.3.2 Regulating electronic structure The atomic M−M’ coupling can lead to the asymmetric of charge distribution around metal dimers, thus adjusting the adsorption/desorption properties of intermediates to improve the ORR performances [86–88]. The atomic Pt–Co NCbased catalyst was prepared by pyrolysis the Co–MOF and then electrochemical activation process [89]. The possible configuration is the (Co-Pt)@N8V4 deduced from the XAS and DFT calculations. The high performance was ascribed to the asymmetry in charge redistribution around Pt–Co centers and the d orbital up-shifting. Similarly, Sun et al. synthesized the Au–Co dual atoms via combining the host–guest and chemical doping strategies, which also demonstrated this encouraging way to fabricate effective electrocatalysts via regulation of D-orbitals symmetry [90]. Obviously, heteronuclear DACs can easily result in this asymmetry of charge distribution of metal dimers, which may have great application in optimizing the adsorption and desorption of intermediates. Introducing the other transition metals with the 3d unoccupied/filled orbitals into the Fe-based SACs can change the electronic structure of active sites [91]. Zhang et al. implanted the Mn–N moieties into Fe/NC to fabricate the atomically dispersed Fe,Mn/NC electrocatalyst by the pyrolysis process [92]. The most possible structure was Fe,Mn/N6–1 model deduced from the AC-STEM, XAS, and DFT simulation. The 57Fe Mossbauer spectroscopy analysis demonstrated the FeIII with the medium-spin structure was predominantly in the catalyst. And the magnetic susceptibility measurement confirmed the low-spin state of neighboring MnIII moieties led to electron delocalization of FeIII and made the spin state of FeIII transition from low spin (t2g5eg0) to intermediate spin (t2g4eg1). This one eg electron filling could penetrate the antibonding π-orbital of oxygen easily, realizing the activation of oxygen (Fig. 9 a–c). DFT calculations further revealed the Fe,Mn/NC could interact with oxygen properly, thus improving the reaction kinetics of ORR. Similarly, Li et al. used the systematic theoretical calculations on protonation free energy to finalize the Fe–Zn pair as the focused catalyst from five metallic elements (Fig. 9d–i) [93]. The introduction of Zn into diatomic sites can change the electronic structure and occur the transition from a semiconductor to half-metal, resulting in spontaneous spin-polarized electrons populated at the Fermi level. Moreover, the elevated protonation energy barrier and sacrificial Zn–N bond breakage can preserve the active center of FeN4, thus improving the durability of Fe-based DACs. These studies emphasize the effect of the change in spin state and spin-polarized electrons for the catalytic reactions, further deepening the understanding of electronic structure regulation. Besides, the electron accumulation through the charge transfer from the transition metal (3d orbitals) to the oxygen (2p anti-bonding orbitals) was demonstrated on the diatoms N3–Fe–Co–N3 structure, which was fabricated via electrospinning and then pyrolyzing [94]. DFT calculations demonstrated the intrinsic defects further promoted the ORR activity by reducing the energy barrier of the O* dissociation. From the above examples, the M−M’ coupling in DACs can result in the obvious change of electronic structure, such as the asymmetric of charge distribution, change in electrical conductivity, and electron accumulation, thus enhancing the catalytic performance via optimizing the adsorption/desorption of intermediates. 4.3.3 Synergy effect The enhanced ORR performance of the DACs is always the result of synergy effect, not only the effect of one aspect [95]. For example, the Co–Fe dual sites on NC were prepared by the carbonization and chemical etching, which was characterized by the HAADF-STEM, EELS, XAS, and DFT calculations [96]. Besides, the authors used the high-energy X-ray diffraction with atomic pair distribution function analysis to probe the structure of both local catalyst environment and host, and the bond information of M−N agreed with the EXAFS results. Moreover, the calculated XANES spectra fit well with the experimental XANES. Theoretical calculations demonstrated that the Co–Fe dimers could provide a low adsorption free energy for O2 through a side-on mode, which could elongate the OO bond to 1.44 Å. Further calculations revealed the ORR activity was attributed to the proper oxygenated species adsorption energies and the strong orbital interactions between the O2 and Co–Fe dimer sites. For the reactions with multiple intermediates, the DACs may provide the synergic cascade mechanism to promote the reaction process. Zhang et al. provided a dual-site cascade mechanism on the Fe/Mn–N x –C catalysts during the ORR process, which was prepared by pyrolysis of the ZnO@PDA–FeMn precursor [78]. Theoretical calculations revealed the synergic mechanism was that the first step of ORR occured on Fe–N x –C site, then the intermediate *OH transferred to adjacent Mn–N x –C site, thus enhancing the adsorption of *OH on Fe–N x –C site. It is worth noting that such synergic cascade mechanisms may have a great influence on reactions with multiple intermediates, which should be considered in the design of catalysts. Especially, the DACs can exhibit the high catalytic performance for OER and ORR simultaneously because of the synergy effect and electronic structure regulation, thus showing the excellent property in Zn-air battery [71,97–106]. Chen et al. prepared the Ir–Co atomic pair via the bimetallic organic framework encapsulation and then pyrolysis, which displayed the E 1/2 of 0.911 V and 330 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 for OER, as well as the cyclability over 450 cycles in Zn–air battery [98]. DFT calculations demonstrated the synergy effects of this atomic pair site, in which the d-orbital energy level of Co was tuned by the incorporation of Ir atom. Finally, the low occupancy of d z 2 orbital contributed to forming the Co–O σ bond, thereby promoting reaction kinetics (Fig. 10 ). The advantages of DACs for ORR can be reflected in elongating the OO bond length, tuning electronic structure of active sites, and the synergy effect. Elongating the OO bond is beneficial to its following dissociation. Tuning electronic structure can optimize the adsorption/desorption property of intermediates, and then promoting the reaction occurring. And the synergy effect that both weakening OO bond and tuning the electronic structure or constructing the cascade reaction can accelerate the reaction process. Thus, the construction of efficient DACs for ORR should consider the above factors comprehensively. Moreover, the optimal metal diatomic combination can be screened by theoretical prediction. 4.4 CO2RR The electroreduction of CO2 to value-added fuels and chemical feedstocks provides an appealing strategy to alleviate the environmental and energy problems [107]. However, the CO2RR is a multielectron-proton transfer process involving various intermediates, corresponding to many reduction products [108]. But the relatively easier process of competitive HER results in the poor selectivity of CO2RR in aqueous electrolyte. Therefore, constructing the efficient catalysts with high selectivity and durability is crucial for practical application of CO2RR. For this reaction that includes multiple reduction products, the faradaic efficiency (FE) is an important parameter to evaluate the electrocatalyst, which is also directly used as the descriptor of the selectivity for CO2RR. For the 2e− products (CO and HCOOH), partial electrocatalysts have exhibited nearly the FE of 100% [109,110]. But for these more electron products, especially the higher alcohols, which have the higher potential application value, the CO2RR performance of current electrocatalysts is unsatisfactory. This is mainly attributed to the complicated intermediates and reaction process, leading to the presence of many competitive reactions [111]. From this aspect, the DACs have the unique advantages in optimizing the adsorption/desorption of intermediates and reaction pathways. 4.4.1 Facilitating CO2 adsorption/activation Optimizing the CO2 adsorption contributes to accelerating the sluggish kinetical reduction process [112]. Cobalt diatomic site catalyst was prepared by pyrolyzing supramolecular precursors, and the atomic structure of a Co2-N coordination was determined by the AC HAADF-STEM, XAS and theoretical analyses [113]. Thereinto, the obtained CoDAC containing 3.5% Co atoms exhibited high CO2 photoreduction performance with 65.0% CH4 selectivity, superior to that of CoSAC. The CoDAC with strong chemical adsorption of CO2 based on the CO2 temperature-programmed desorption was attributed to adjacent Co atoms, which provided dual sites to adsorb the C and O atoms simultaneously. And the STM images indicated the hybridization between the Co (d orbital) and C and O atoms (p orbitals). Moreover, the CO* intermediates easily became the CHO* rather than direct desorbing based on the in-situ FTIR, thus resulting in high CH4 selectivity. Theoretical analysis demonstrated that the charge enrichment of dual-atom Co sites contributed to optimizing the adsorption of the rate-limiting COOH* and CHO* intermediates and reducing the activation energy barrier. This study provides the comparison in catalytic performance between CoDAC and CoSAC, and the huge performance difference confirms the advantage of DACs from the side. The efficient CO2 activation can also enhance the sluggish kinetics reaction [114]. One representative example is the Cu atom-pair catalyst [49]. The Cu1 0-Cu1 x + pairs were confirmed by the AC HAADF-STEM, XAS, and theoretical calculations. Experimental and theoretical results suggested the Cu1 0-Cu1 x + site promoted the CO2 activation via a ‘biatomic activating bimolecular’ mechanism, which was that the Cu1 x + with adsorbed H2O molecule could stabilize the CO2 chemisorbed on neighboring Cu1 0 (Fig. 11 ). This resulted in a FECO of over 92%. This work demonstrates the different active sites to adsorb different molecules can reduce the activation energy, and this atomic level interface design may provide new opportunities for other more complex catalytic reactions. Thus, optimizing the CO2 adsorption and activation is beneficial for accelerating the reduction process, which provides the guide to design the DACs. 4.4.2 Regulating electronic structure The interaction of adjacent diatom provides the opportunities to adjust the electronic structure of active sites [36,115–122]. For example, the Ni-Zn dual-atom sites coordinated with NC, confirmed by AC HAADF-STEM and XAS characterizations, were prepared by carbonization and acidification [36]. Theoretical calculations revealed that Ni–Zn coordination modified their d-states, strengthening the electronic interaction between the intermediate and catalyst, which led to reduce the energy barrier of thermodynamic and activation energy. These advantages endowed this catalyst with a high FECO of > 90% in the wide voltage window. Similarly, the electron transfer/redistribution between the adjacent metal sites was also demonstrated in other DACs for CO2RR, such as Ni/CuNC [115], NiSn atomic-pair [116], Pd2 DAC [117], and Zn/CoNC [118], which all revealed the electronic structure regulation resulted in optimizing the intermediates adsorption, reaction barriers and pathways, finally facilitating the CO2RR. The d-d orbital coupling of metal dimer can induce the change of electronic structure. The Ni–Fe dual-atom anchored on NG was prepared for CO2RR and OER by pyrolysis and acidification [120]. Experimental and theoretical analyses demonstrated the Fe in Ni–Fe heteroatomic pair was the catalytic center, and the strong d-d orbital coupling with Ni resulted in decrease of orbital energy levels and electron delocalization, weakening the *CO binding strength. Meanwhile, the electron transferred from Fe to Ni and N, resulting in the Fe center with the large Bader charge and high oxidation state, promoting CO2 activation and CO desorption (Fig. 12 ). These advantages synergistically boosted CO2RR and OER performance. This work provides systematical discussion about the electronic structure regulation, rather than focusing on only one aspect. Similarly, the Fe acted as the active site and Cu acted as the activity promoter were also demonstrated by DFT calculations on dual-atom Cu/Fe–NC [123]. And from another perspective, the regulation of electronic structure can also make the bimetallic atoms serve as different active sites for different reactions [124], such as the Zn–Ln dual atomic catalysts to obtain syngas, where the Zn and La sites were responsible for the generation of CO and H2, respectively [121]. The tuning of electronic structure can lead to the electron transfer/redistribution and decrease of orbital energy levels, contributing to the CO2 activation and the adsorption/desorption of intermediates. Especially, the regulation of electronic structure makes the bimetallic atoms as different active sites for different intermediates, which should be paid attention. 4.4.3 Synergy effect For the multiple intermediate reactions, dual active sites can always exhibit the synergy effect for the adsorption/desorption of intermediates [33,125–127]. For example, the diatomic Ni–Fe sites on NC were prepared by pyrolysis [128]. The coordination structure of N3–Ni–Fe–N3 was deduced from the AC HAADF-STEM, XAS and theoretical simulation. DFT studies showed that the neighboring Ni–Fe centers synergistically decreased the reaction barrier for the COOH* formation and CO desorption, and one CO pre-adsorption mechanism was proposed (Fig. 13 a). Similar synergy was also reported on the Fe–Cu diatoms (Fig. 13b and c) [129]. Besides, the synergy effect of dual-atom active sites was studied by DFT calculations [130], and the results were that Fe-(Fe, Co, Ni, Cu)@C2N tended to form C2H4, while the Cu-(Co, Ni, Cu)@C2N was beneficial for CH4 formation, and the binding strength of co-adsorbed *CO + *CO was important for CO2 electroreduction to C2 products (Fig. 13d and e). Although the theoretical prediction has proven the high performance of DACs in this field, the experimental results of current catalysts are unsatisfactory. Importantly, the synergy effect of DACs can be reflected in the whole reduction process. Zhang et al. fabricated the Ni dual-atom sites with the N3–Ni–Ni–N3 structure based on the results of AC HAADF-STEM, EELS, XAS and theoretical simulation [33]. Combining the theoretical calculations and in situ XAFS measurement, they revealed the Ni2N6OH functioned as the real active sites for fast CO2RR kinetics and slow HER kinetics. And the synergy effect was reflected in that OHad made the Ni dual-atom sites with an electron-rich catalytic environment, thus promoting the CO2RR process by optimizing CO2 activation, *COOH formation, and *CO desorption. Notably, this work also discloses the effect of DACs in the regulation of the catalytic microenvironment, which can influence the selectivity of the reduction product. Thus, fabricating the DACs to synergistically regulate the CO2 activation, the adsorption/desorption of *COOH and *CO intermediate, the competing reaction of HER, can boost the performance of CO2RR. 4.4.4 Breaking scaling relations Theoretical analysis revealed the DACs with multiple active sites could break the scaling relations of active sites and intermediates towards CO2RR [131–133]. For example, ten heteronuclear and five homonuclear graphene-based dual metal catalysts (a N3–M1–M2–N3 moiety) were also discussed for CO2RR [132]. Three DACs (Cu–Mn, Ni–Mn and Ni–Fe) were considered as promising catalysts after screening via calculating the adsorption strength of OH* and COOH* species. Moreover, the linear relationship between the ΔG COOH* and ΔG CO* values was absent for DACs, leading to a high activity for CO2 electroreduction to CO, and the reason of this was attributed to that the adsorption of COOH* on DACs was bidentate, and CO* was monodentate. However, breaking of scaling relationship may be unsuitable for all the DACs because of the complex adsorption structure. Besides, twenty-one kinds of heteronuclear transition-metal dimers embedded in monolayer C2N were studied by theoretical calculations [131]. The results showed that the binding energy of the key intermediates on metal dimers was completely decoupled, leading the absence of the limitation of overpotential. And the proper dual-metal atoms could serve as the *C and *O binding sites respectively, which resulted in breaking the above-mentioned scaling relations. Based on the structural stability, activity (the binding energies of *COOH, *CO, and *CHO), and selectivity (the difference of limiting potentials for CO2RR and HER, UL(CO2)-UL(H2)), the CuCr/C2N and CuMn/C2N were regarded as promising catalysts for CO2 electroreduction to CH4 (Fig. 14 ). Besides, the Pt2, AgNi, Pd2, and AgPt supported on defective graphene were also reported as the promising candidates for CO2 electroreduction to CH4 by the first-principles approach, which also emphasized the importance of breaking scaling relations [133]. The adjacent dual active centers could easily break the scaling relations in the adsorption energies of different intermediates, thus reducing the limiting potential. From these results, fabricating the multiple active sites to break scaling relations is an efficient strategy to enhance the performance of multi-intermediate reactions. However, current research in this field mainly focuses on theoretical aspect, with little emphasis on experimental research, which might be paid much attention. 4.4.5 Promoting the CC coupling The adjacent bimetallic atoms in DACs may provide the proper active sites for CC coupling, which is always regarded as the RDS for C2 products [134]. Zheng et al. prepared the atomically dispersed Cu–N x catalyst to tune selectivity via changing Cu doping concentrations [135]. Experimental results showed that adjacent Cu atoms were beneficial for CC coupling and produced C2H4, while single atom site was favored for CH4 formation. DFT calculations confirmed two adjacent Cu-N2 sites contributed to forming C2H4 by two *CO binding, but the isolated/neighboring Cu–N4 and isolated Cu–N2 sites favored CH4 formation. Besides, Experimental and mechanistic investigation verified that the Cl- bridged dimer Cu units resulted in charge enrichment on the surrounding Cu centers, which provided moderate adsorption energy to realize the CC coupling [136]. Theoretically, the adjacent Cu atom should have great potential in realizing the CC coupling, but the research of CC coupling on DACs to obtain the multi-carbon hydrocarbons and oxygenates is not enough, which may be the focus of this field. 4.4.6 Ideal machine learning platform The relatively definite active sites and coordination environment of DACs provide proper platform for catalyst screening [137,138]. Sun et al. chose six crucial adsorption intermediates (CO, COOH, CHO, H, O and OH) to screen the efficient CO2RR catalysts based on the DFT and microkinetics modeling (Fig. 15 ) [139]. As a result, the Cu2, CuMn, and CuNi dimers on graphene with adjacent single vacancies (labeled as XY@2SV), exhibited high performance for CO2RR. Thereinto, Cu2@2SV preferred CO generation, and MnCu@2SV was selective toward CH4 formation, while NiCu@2SV promoted CH3OH production. It is worth noting that this large-scale screening-based DFT and machine learning will accelerate the discovery of efficient CO2RR catalysts, thus providing guidance and motivation for experimental research. Obviously, DFT calculations combined with active machine learning can also expand to other catalytic systems, which will undoubtedly become the research focus. From above examples, we conclude the DACs have great advantages in this multiple intermediates and pathways reaction. And the applications of DACs in CO2RR have exhibited the advantages of facilitating CO2 adsorption and activation, regulating electronic structure, synergy effect, breaking scaling relations, promoting the CC coupling, and ideal machine learning platform. Thereinto, the application of DACs for CO2RR to C2+ products, especially the Cu-based DACs, may become the focus of future research, and the adjacent bimetallic active centers of DACs bring great possibilities in tuning the intermediates adsorption/desorption and constructing the tandem reactions. 4.5 NRR The NRR is considered a promising approach for the ammonia synthesis with respect to the Haber-Bosch process with high energy consumption [140]. However, the N2 molecule is highly stable because of the strong triple bond and large energy gap [141,142], thus the reaction kinetics is much sluggish. Besides, the partial current density of NRR is very small due to the serious competing HER, which indicates the minute ammonia yield easily suffers from the ubiquitous contaminants plague during experimental practices. Thus, seeking the high-efficient catalysts to increase the real ammonia yield in an order of magnitude is still the focus of research in this field. Currently, the NRR is considered to proceed the dissociative or associative reaction mechanisms [5]. But the N2 activation on the active center is always considered as the potential-limiting step [143]. The efficient NRR catalysts should be beneficial for N2 activation and the subsequent hydrogenation steps, and while suppressing the HER process. The application of DACs in NRR mainly concentrates on the N2 activation and reducing the rate-determining step barrier. 4.5.1 Boosting N2 activation The special metallic diatom is beneficial for the chemisorption of N2 and activation of stable NN bond. The diatomic Pd–Cu sites on NC were prepared by a dissolution-and-carbonization method to prove this point [144]. The AC HAADF-STEM, XAS, and DFT calculations suggested the PdN2CuN2_556 structure was the active center to facilitate NRR. The Cu introduced could shift the partial DOS of Pd, thus promoting the d-2p* coupling between Pd and adsorbed N2. This would enhance the chemisorption and activated protonation of N2, as well as suppressed HER, eventually enhancing the selectivity of NRR by reducing the energy of the potential-determining step (PDS). Similarly, the Zn–Fe atomic pairs anchored on NC [145] and the atomic Fe and Mo dimers on defect-rich graphene [146] also demonstrated the favorable of N2 activation and reduction in the barrier of PDS. Although these studies have demonstrated the advantages of DACs in NRR, the catalytic performance is still far from satisfactory. Thus, screening the optimal dual metal atoms to effectively activate the stable NN bond is worth studying. 4.5.2 Reducing the rate-determining step barrier DFT calculations also demonstrated that the adjacent metal dimers are beneficial for optimizing the adsorption/desorption of NRR intermediates, thus reducing the RDS barrier. For example, DFT calculations revealed the metal dimers (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni) anchored on C2N were superior to their SAAs. Thereinto, the Mn2-C2N endowed the highest catalytic activity with the lowest RDS potential of − 0.23 V (NHNH2* + H+ + e− → NH2NH2*) [147]. Another theoretical prediction showed the binary FeRh on N-doped porous graphene was the best catalyst because of its lowest limiting PDS potential for the N2H* species formation [148]. Besides, the first principles high-throughput screening based on five-step criteria, which were the high thermodynamic stability, sufficient N2 activation, low energy cost, and high NRR selectivity, was performed among 23 transition metal centers to discuss their NRR performance. And only Fe2/g-CN can satisfy above screening criteria (Fig. 16 ). Moreover, the authors found the limiting potential was related with the electron donation from transition metal to N2, thus determining the N2 activation and *NH3 formation [149]. Unfortunately, these conclusions are all the results of theoretical calculations, and there is no experimental data to prove the efficiency of these catalysts. Although some encouraging results have been obtained, there are still many challenges in the NRR. The N2 activation, nitrogen scaling relations, and the competing HER process seriously limit the activity of NRR catalysts. The DACs for NRR have exhibited advantages in N2 activation and reducing the RDS barrier. Thus, designing the proper DACs based on the above DFT calculation will accelerate the investigation process of efficient catalysts, and the innovation of catalytic system of NRR is also crucial for improving the catalytic performance, which may the focus of future research. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Overall, this review has mainly summarized the advantages of DACs for different catalytic reactions. A detailed comparison of their catalytic performances is listed in Table S1. Based on the above experimental and theoretical results, some significant conclusions are obtained: (i) The adjacent dual metal atoms provide the co-adsorption sites for the molecule, which is beneficial for the molecule activation by elongating the chemical bond or adjusting adsorption layout, etc. (ii) The strong interaction of dual metal atoms contributes to regulating the electronic structure, resulting in the covalence transformation or electron delocalization, thus optimizing the adsorption/desorption of intermediates to promote the reaction process. (iii) For the reaction of multiple intermediates and steps, the synergy effect of DACs can be reflected in breaking the scaling relations and/or constructing the cascade reaction to accelerate the reaction process. (iv) The molecular nature of active sites and the relatively definite structure of DACs make them as attractive platforms to study the reaction mechanism or screen for efficient catalysts. Furthermore, compared to other small size catalysts, the DACs can guarantee the atomic utilization while providing a relatively simple and clear coordination structure, which is important in designing catalysts and constructing theoretical models to study mechanisms. Despite the great potential in this field, the development of DACs still faces several major challenges. Here, several critical challenges and research directions for the future development of DACs are discussed below. (i) Breakthroughs in characterization techniques. Currently, the structures of DACs are all deduced from the AC STEM, XAS, and theoretical analysis. However, the above characterization techniques have their drawbacks, making it difficult to accurately characterize the dinuclear structure. Thus, more solid evidence to verify the dual-atom structure precisely is urgently needed. Besides, the remarkable performance difference compared to SACs or clusters might also be the sideways evidence for DACs, which should be provided if possible. (ii) Clarifying the synthesis mechanism clearly. The catalysts with only dual-atom structure have not been reported so far, and most reported studies only provided the synthesis procedure, but the mechanism or the reasons for synthesis of DACs are ambiguous. This may require to clarify the effects of ligands, coordination environment, and structural evolution in forming the DACs, etc. Clarifying the synthesis mechanism exactly contributes to improving the ratio of dimer structure and repeatability, which are worth much attention. Thereinto, designing the precursors with special coordination structures while monitoring the diatom formation process with in situ ESTEM during pyrolysis is an appealing method for controlled DACs synthesis. Besides, the ALD technique with special substrates to adjust the atom deposition and/or combined with other treatments may also be a good choice. (iii) Revealing the active sites under working conditions. The structures of catalysts always undergo the reconstruction/evolution during the reaction process. Revealing the real active sites under realistic reaction conditions plays a key role in understanding the reaction mechanism, which mainly relies on in-situ characterization techniques (in-situ Raman, IR, XAS, etc.). The application of in situ characterization techniques to monitor the structural reconstruction/evolution, including the coordination structure, valence state, etc., thus revealing the real active sites to clarify the reaction mechanism is always the focus of frontier research, which is also beneficial to design the effective catalysts. (iv) Combining the machine learning and DFT calculations. To accelerate the discovery of efficient catalysts, the machine-learning accelerated, high-throughput DFT framework is strongly suggested to be used to screen materials and explore the activity origin, as well as the design principles for DACs for different reactions. The combination of them will no doubt accelerate the optimizing process of catalysts, which should be considered for the future research. Although there are many challenges, the DACs are still worthy of attention due to their great advantages. Kaihua Liu got his Ph.D. degree in materials science from Jilin University in 2019. And then he worked as a project hired personnel at Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He is currently a lecturer at Yantai University. His research interests focus on the design and synthesis of electrocatalysts for catalytic reactions, such as water splitting and carbon dioxide reduction, etc. Jing Li is an assistant research fellow at Yantai University. She obtained her Ph.D. degree at Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (2015). Prior to this appointment, she worked as postdoctoral researcher at Shandong University. She is currently conducting research on the design and application of nanostructured energy materials for Li-S batteries. Yuanyuan Liu received her Ph.D. degree from Tianjin University. She is a lecturer at Yantai University. Her research is focused on rational design, synthesis, and fundamental investigation of key materials and components for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. Meiri Wang is a professor at Yantai University. Before that, she was an associate researcher at Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her current research focuses on the research and development of key materials and components for high performance lithium sulfur batteries. Hongtao Cui is a professor at Yantai University. He received Ph.D. degree from Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2002. Then, he worked as a postdoctoral fellow in Instituto de Ciencia de Materiales de Madrid. His research focuses on building ordered nanostructures for application in energy storage devices.

coredata.dc:description: The dual-metal-atom catalysts (DACs) have aroused much attention as they possess the advantages of single-atom and metal alloy catalysts. And the DACs have exhibited enhanced performance in various electrocatalytic reactions, such as hydrogen/oxygen evolution and oxygen/carbon dioxide/nitrogen reduction. In this review, we mainly overview the latest understanding of the advantages of DACs for these reactions. This review will start with the familiar characterization methods for DACs, then the primary synthesis strategies for DACs will be discussed. Emphasis is given to the advantages of DACs in catalytic reactions, including the adsorption and activation, electronic structure regulation, breaking scaling relations, reducing energy barriers, cascading and coupling, synergy effect, and providing mechanism research platforms. Finally, personal perspectives and challenges for the further development of DACs are briefly discussed.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
coredata.dc:title: Dual metal atom catalysts: Advantages in electrocatalytic reactions
